Oh, those summer nights! It's the #SummerSolstice, the longest day in the Northern Hemisphere—and the shortest in the Southern Hemisphere where winter starts.

Glance up tonight for a planetary cameo, with Mars and Venus just beside the Moon: https://go.nasa.gov/3CDqMaj

Enceladus, Saturn's icy moon, is known for its geysers that erupt with water from a subsurface ocean. 

Scientists have just detected phosphorus—an uncommon element that's a key building block for life—in the plumes that these geysers spray: https://go.nasa.gov/43FVtY1

Astronauts-eye view 

Take a look through the helmet cams of 
@Astro_Woody
 and Steve Bowen as they prepare to install a roll-out solar array during today's spacewalk.

Suits are set to battery power and today's spacewalk is underway!

This is Hoburg's second spacewalk and Bowen's 10th—tying a record for most spacewalks made by a U.S. astronaut.

Love space but nervous to travel 1.8 billion miles? That’s okay!

Leave your mark by having your name engraved on the 
@EuropaClipper
 spacecraft! 

#SendYourName here: https://go.nasa.gov/449nDLd

How do places on Mars get their name? 

More than 2,000 locations on the Red Planet have official names, recognizing places on Earth, explorers, and even cartoon characters. Learn what inspires names for Martian hills, craters, and rocks: https://go.nasa.gov/3CmCYMm

Later this month, we're opening the Earth Information Center—a hybrid exhibit that offers an interactive look at our changing planet.

Media are invited to a ribbon-cutting ceremony on Wednesday, June 21, at NASA Headquarters in Washington: https://go.nasa.gov/43STHT7

To-do: Become a NASA Intern 

Today our #NASAInterns completed their first week at 
@NASA
. Already these #ArtemisGeneration interns are putting their talent and creativity to work for the betterment of all. 

Welcome to the team!

"'NASA for all.' That's something that I think is really important because we are the universe, right? We are made of star stuff."

Celebrate #Pride and learn how Rebecca Sirmons helps tell the story of the universe as NASA TV's executive producer: http://go.nasa.gov/3IVxzj7

There’s space for everyone this #PrideMonth, and we’re celebrating the LGBTQI+ employees who help us reach for the stars, examine humanity’s place in the universe, and study our home planet: http://go.nasa.gov/3C9ncnU

Hurricane season in the Atlantic begins today. Our unique perspective from space allows us to study storms and their evolution, providing data to support forecasting and disaster responses: https://go.nasa.gov/3fYNZYE
